Q: Aspect-oriented programming vs. object-oriented programming A:

First of all, AOP will not replace OOP. AOP extends OOP. The ideas and practices of OOP stay relevant. Having a good object design will probably make it easier to extend it with aspects.

I think the ideas that AOP brings are important. We need to work out ways to implement cross-cutting concerns over different classes in your program without having to change the classes themselves. But I think the AOP will eventually just become part of other tools we use and not a separate tool or technique. We already see this happening.

A couple of dynamic languages, like Ruby and Python, have language constructs, like mixins, that solve the same problems. This looks a lot like AOP, but it is better integrated in the language.

Spring and Castle and a couple of other dependency injection framework have options to add behaviour to the classes they inject. This is a way of doing runtime-weaving, and I think this has a lot of potential.

I don't think you'll have to learn a completely new paradigm to use AOP. The ideas are interesting, but they are slowly being absorbed by existing tools and languages. Just stay informed and try out these tools.

Q: Is there any limitations to number of arguments in variadic functions? A:

There is no specific limit in the standard.
According to the variadic functions documentation, they:

Allows a function to accept any number of extra arguments.

(emphasis is mine)

But in practice each implementation has some limit based on available resources (e.g. stack memory) etc.

This is a relevant post: Variadic Functions - Is there an argument limit?.
(it is for C not C++, but still relevant because variadic functions are actually a legacy from C).

Note that the situation is similar with C++ variadic templates.

Q: The Working Principle of CSS Negative Margins A:

Negative margins allow elements to overlap because they change an element's layout footprint without shrinking its actual size.

  • Element A (margin-bottom: -140px): This doesn't shrink the box. Instead, it tells the browser to start the next element 140px "early." You are essentially telling the flow: "I am 200px tall, but only occupy 60px of vertical space."

  • Element B (margin-top: -40px): Unlike bottom margins, a negative top margin pulls the element itself upward.

In your case, Element A "invited" Element B into its boundaries by shrinking its footprint. Then, Element B pulled itself even further up using its own negative top margin. Since both elements remain in the normal document flow, they simply occupy the same visual coordinates.

Edit: clarified that the overlap is caused by Element A’s negative bottom margin; Element B’s negative top margin does not add further movement here.
